156.text: Today we are going to talk about the role of business

158.text: in reducing poverty with people immersed in the work

164.text: to try to give you a wider view of the best thinking in this area.

168.text: We’ve got representatives from the private foundation sector,

171.text: a giant multinational, a giant government and the structures expert

176.text: who wants to help business people in high poverty areas

178.text: organize and protect what they build.

181.text: They are C.D. Glin, President and C.E.O. of the U.S. African Development Foundation,

187.text: Cherie Blair of the Cherie Blair Foundation for Women,

191.text: Charlotte Oades, Global Vice President for Women's Economic Development

195.text: at the Coca-Cola Company and Bart Houlahan, Co-Founder of B-Lab Company.

202.text: I’d like to just start with a quick run across the panel

205.text: to give our audience an idea of what your organization does

209.text: and how its design reflects your thinking about using business

214.text: as a catalyst to do poverty alleviation.

220.text: So, the U.S. African Development Foundation

222.text: was established about twenty years after USAID.

226.text: So I’m sure everybody in this room knows United States Agency

228.text: for International Development and very few people in this room probably know

232.text: what the U.S. African Development Foundation is.

234.text: And the reason why we were established was really to be a counter

239.text: to big development from a big donor country.

243.text: We focus on grassroots enterprise development

249.text: economic growth for localized lives using local enterprise and how do we do that?

254.text: I like to frame it from our name, our name is very, very easy the U.S.,

259.text: the U.S. Government, African Development Foundation.

261.text: That ‘A’, it does stand for African but also about being African led.

265.text: So, all of our management, all of our operations in twenty plus countries

269.text: are led by African nationals, led by local community members,

273.text: so we don’t have any contractors, we don’t have any ex-pats,

277.text: we are really African led in our model.

279.text: We’re agile and adaptable because all of our grant making,

282.text: this is seed capital linked with technical assistance, is designed from the bottom up.

287.text: It’s designed by the people in the local communities

290.text: and we using the ‘D’ are demand driven, we’re demand responsive to their needs,

295.text: to the opportunities that they bring and really meet them where they are.

299.text: We bring the seed capital, we bring technical assistance, but they bring the what.

303.text: What is the need of that community,

305.text: how do we really advance ourselves out of poverty

308.text: and we look in three specific areas:

310.text: agriculture, off-grid energy and youth-led enterprise.

314.text: Now the last thing, so the agility is there,

317.text: a speedboat in the ocean liners of foreign assistance,

320.text: we are the speed boat if you will.

322.text: Thirty million dollars a year directly implemented in countries,

326.text: directly funding local grassroots cooperatives in organizations.

331.text: What I like to think about the foundation aspect of really being about first mile.

336.text: So, we’re all here at Skoll and we think about last mile development.

339.text: Well, why do we think about last mile?

340.text: Well, I think about it because I was a Peace Corps volunteer

342.text: and I went from Washington D.C. to the far reaches in southern Africa,

347.text: where the paved road ended, my job began, because I was going there.

351.text: And we think about last mile because we distributing something to people.

354.text: Well at USADF, we talk about first mile because the first point of contact,

358.text: the first phase of funding, the first step of really looking at local economic growth,

364.text: So, we’re not bringing something to them, we’re taking something from out of them

367.text: and expanding and growing it and making it more prosperous

371.text: and putting them on a pathway to prosperity.

373.text: So, we really talk about being African led,

375.text: being demand driven and being first mile focused,

378.text: and using taxpayer dollars to catalyze that change in those local communities.

384.text: Well, at the Cherie Blair Foundation,

386.text: we believe that if we empower women so that they can have their own money,

391.text: then they can make their own choices.

394.text: And so we work with women entrepreneurs,

396.text: small and medium size business people,

399.text: who want to grow and expand their businesses

403.text: and we do that by doing what we say is looking at the three C’s.

408.text: We believe that a woman entrepreneur needs three things.

413.text: She needs confidence and I don’t need to tell you all here

416.text: that so many parts of the world, including even in this country,

420.text: women are often told what they can’t do rather than what they can do,

424.text: and so confidence is a really important part of that.

427.text: So, our programs always help with women's confidence.

431.text: We then look at the women's capacity,

434.text: so we do a huge amount of business training, financial literacy training,

439.text: to help women get those skills which are not necessarily naturally acquired.

446.text: Many of the women who work do have natural talent,

448.text: whether it’s in the fashion industry or in science and technology,

453.text: or engineering, or medicine even, but they don’t necessarily have the business skills.

459.text: It’s one thing to know how to deliver a service

463.text: and it’s another thing to know how to read a balance sheet,

465.text: and so we do a lot of business skills training, that's our second C.

470.text: And our third C, and the most difficult one to crack, is access to capital.

474.text: Because we live in a world where if you want ten dollars

478.text: then these days micro-financing is going to find a solution for you.

482.text: And if you want ten million, or more,

485.text: then venture capital will probably find a solution for you.

489.text: If you want twenty five, fifty, even a hundred thousand

494.text: to grow and expand your business,

495.text: which is probably already employing 10-15 people,

499.text: but you want to take it to the next level, it’s very difficult to get that capital.

504.text: And so, we are constantly devising and looking for ways to help our women

509.text: entrepreneurs raise capital and because we believe that

515.text: if you’re talking about development then you’re talking about

518.text: empowering women to drive the expansion of their businesses.

523.text: So they’re not only employing their own families

527.text: but they really are providing job opportunities for men and women,

532.text: boys and girls, in their communities.

535.text: And we have three different ways of doing that, three programs,

538.text: because our programs are driven by technology.

541.text: Because in the 21st century, technology can help us reach people

546.text: we haven’t been able to reach before,

548.text: give them access to information that’s been inaccessible to them before,

552.text: and to link people across the world, to make transactions,

557.text: to help each other ,to loan money to each other.

562.text: So, our first program is our Global Mentoring Platform and this is a platform,

567.text: where we reach out to women who are having businesses and employing people.

572.text: They have to have access to the Internet,

574.text: which in many parts of the world of course can be difficult,

578.text: and they have to be able to speak English.

580.text: So we’re not talking about bottom of the pyramid women here,

583.text: we’re talking about women with enterprises

586.text: and we match these women with men and women mentors all over the world.

591.text: So, to date we’re in over a hundred countries

594.text: because we partner with local NGO’s who are doing business training

598.text: and we offer them this service.

600.text: An add-on service which is a year's mentoring, whereby the woman is given a mentor,

606.text: who for two hours a month will help them on their business journey, with a specific plan.

611.text: And we have built a worldwide community there, which not only is a dating service,

617.text: is actually a community, which talks with each other and works and supports each other.

623.text: Then our next program is what we call our Enterprise Development Programs

626.text: and this is much more face-to-face, on the ground business training,

631.text: financial literacy training, which we do in different geographies

635.text: and in that program we’ve developed our blended learning approach,

639.text: which again, uses technology to enable women entrepreneurs

644.text: to be able to get the sort of access to the business skills training they need,

648.text: without having to give up and huge chunks of time away from their business.

653.text: And we’ve found that that’s has been very, very successful

656.text: because women like that flexibility, that a combination of some face to face training

662.text: and a lot of other training delivered over technology, really works.

667.text: And then our third program, is our Mobile Phone Program, which is aimed much more,

672.text: at towards the bottom of the pyramid women,

675.text: providing basic skills training and information to help women

680.text: by using the mobile phone, either to learn business skills,

685.text: possibly to develop a small business

687.text: around selling mobile phone time or mobile money services.

692.text: And finally, we’ve developed a number of apps

695.text: which just make life easier for women who have got small businesses,

702.text: by using their mobile phone to give them advantage of technology.

713.text: I lead the, what we call, ‘5by20 Initiative’ at Coca-Cola,

718.text: which is our Women's Economic Empowerment Initiative.

722.text: We made a global commitment to enable the economic empowerment

725.text: of  five million women entrepreneurs across our global value chain by 2020

732.text: and this was a commitment we made at the end of 2010.

736.text: So, as you think about Coca-Cola Company,

741.text: it’s obviously very well known for its global brands and it’s a global company,

745.text: but actually the way we operate is very, very local business.

747.text: So, as we look at that, we want to hire people locally,

753.text: we all live and work in the local community,

756.text: so it’s really, really important to us that the community is thriving,

761.text: it’s sustainable and that’s critical for, obviously, us as a business to grow,

767.text: and so the two go hand in hand.

769.text: So, we see women as being absolutely critical to that.

772.text: Women are not only the pillars of the local community

776.text: but we all know that if you can, as Cherie has said,

779.text: if you can enable a woman to actually earn her own livelihood, have her own business,

783.text: then the ripple effect of that is enormous on the community

787.text: and it’s not just the woman who benefits but it’s her family,

791.text: her children then are able to go to school because she invests in them,

794.text: she spends in the local economy.

796.text: So, there’s this massive ripple effect

798.text: and obviously that’s good for businesses to then operate in that community.

803.text: So, that’s the reason we believe this is so important.

807.text: And as from a business perspective, the critical thing,

813.text: I think from my perspective, is that it is looking across those small businesses,

818.text: that we would have the opportunity to touch and that might not be a business yet,

822.text: it might be helping women to set up businesses from scratch

825.text: or it may be helping her to grow one that she already has.

829.text: And we look at it right across what we would call our value chain,

832.text: so it starts with smallholder farmers that might be growing fruit

836.text: or any kind of crop that we might be able to take into our beverages at some point.

841.text: It could be any kind of supplier.

845.text: In Africa, we have committed to say fifty percent of all new distributors must be women.

851.text: We look at small neighborhood stores,

854.text: you know, the small businesses which are very popular for women to set up

858.text: because it’s close to home, it’s not in an area that's unsafe for them to go into

864.text: and they sell things in the local community.

867.text: We also look at recycling businesses and waste picking businesses

872.text: and we also look at artisan businesses

875.text: that make things from recycled beverage packaging,

877.text: often combining them with indigenous materials.

880.text: So, many different kinds because we are so global but so local,

887.text: we do work very much at the bottom of the pyramid

890.text: and I believe that linking it to the business,

894.text: so that we can help those businesses grow,

898.text: is actually the way to make it truly sustainable.

901.text: And Charlotte, you’re even actually wearing one of your artisan’s…?

904.text: I am, yeah this is made from recycled plastic bottles from the Amazon,

909.text: from one of  our artisans in the Amazon.

915.text: So, B-Lab’s a non-profit, we’re trying to directly the address the question of this panel:

920.text: How do we get business more engaged in alleviating poverty,

928.text: Our approach is pretty straightforward, we’re trying to redefine success in business,

932.text: we believe in a generation's time there needs to be a different way

936.text: we all think about what success means.

941.text: It’s going to lead to require companies not just being best in the world

945.text: To get there, there’s going to need to be some infrastructure put in place.

949.text: The first is, we need new metrics, right?

952.text: As we think about business, it needs to not just be about financial accomplishments,

957.text: it needs to include community engagement,

964.text: Those need to be included in what we think about as a successful business.

969.text: Secondly, the truth is, if we want different outcomes from business,

974.text: we’ve got to change the rules,

975.text: and that means we need to address shareholder primacy.

978.text: And so for us, that means a new legal framework,

982.text: that requires companies to create not only value for their shareholders,

986.text: but also for society and the environment.

987.text: And then third and finally, we have to address transparency.

993.text: not just about their financial results

994.text: but also about their social and environmental impact.

997.text: Our theory of change, again, pretty straightforward.

1000.text: We find leaders, best in class companies, we give them an identity,

1003.text: we call them Certified B Corporations.

1005.text: I’m sure almost everybody here is familiar with Fair Trade.

1009.text: Fair Trade is to coffee what Certified B Corp is to a good business.

1014.text: To be certified, you’ve got to demonstrate the highest standards

1018.text: of social and environmental performance as evidenced

1021.text: through something called our B Impact Assessment.

1023.text: Secondly, you’ve got to embed in the actual governance of the company,

1028.text: a commitment to stakeholders, so it’s in the DNA of the business.

1030.text: And then third and finally, you need to be transparent with your results.

1033.text: We have about 2,100 Certified B Corporations in 54 different countries,

1040.text: Commonality, they’re all using business as a force for good.

1044.text: Our objective, after identifying these leaders,

1046.text: is then to provide easy tools for others to follow.

1048.text: So, the impact assessment we use for the certification,

1051.text: it’s free, it’s a public good, anybody can use, it includes case studies,

1057.text: We have about 60,000 companies using that tool as an internal management tool,

1061.text: to try to be more impactful.

1063.text: The second scaling tool for us, allowing companies

1066.text: to follow the lead of the community, is a new legal framework.

1070.text: It’s literally a new legal type of corporation, it’s called the Benefit Corp.  Okay?

1077.text: We have passed now in 32 states in the United States and about six months ago in Italy.

1082.text: There are eight countries that are considering it currently.

1085.text: It was recommended by the G7 for all countries to adopt this new legal entity.

1091.text: So, think traditional corporation, think non-profit, and then sitting next to it,

1094.text: something called the Benefit Corp that requires a company

1097.text: to create shareholder value and social value simultaneously.

1101.text: Those two pieces work together to try to allow companies

1104.text: to follow the lead of the community as Certified B Corp.

1106.text: The long term objective, as I said, is to redefine success in business

1110.text: so that we’re getting a shared and durable prosperity through the business community.

1113.text: Now you know what our panelists do, I’m interested in what was learned along the way.

1121.text: Not stories of failure but stories of adaptation.

1125.text: Plans are, I mean, smart people make plans and then they go in and, like war plans,

1132.text: they sometimes don’t survive the first shot.

1135.text: There are things that you have to change, modify, reshape to local conditions.

1142.text: I’m wondering if in all your cases there have been times where something that

1146.text: looked great on paper, needed to be adapted

1150.text: because of things that you just don’t know until you’re actually doing it?

1155.text: One of the things, I think, in the philanthropic space

1159.text: and looking at grant funding, because you make a grant therefore you are good.

1164.text: And that sort of, that, we have money

1167.text: and we make grants to poor and vulnerable people

1169.text: in hard to reach under-served communities, in the Horn of Africa,

1173.text: in the Sahel, in the Great Lakes region.

1175.text: So, we make a grant to an organization,

1178.text: we link them with technical assistance and therefore we’ve done good in the world.

1182.text: And one of the things coming into this role is,

1185.text: we had to do some critical analysis about what are we really trying to do?

1188.text: Are we trying to make grants or are we trying to make change?

1191.text: And if we’re trying to make change we need to be intentional

1194.text: in a very different way and so we started structuring our grant

1197.text: making around a first phase of funding.

1199.text: A phased approach, really again that first mile,

1202.text: that first phase of funding, your operational assistance.

1204.text: And taking an agricultural co-operative and saying, your governance structure,

1208.text: your books in order, your financial management tool, some operational assistance.

1212.text: And then there’s the next phase of funding and really about enterprise expansion.

1216.text: And for years, we sort of did operational assistance,

1219.text: we did enterprise expansion, and we would stop.

1222.text: So then I come along and I start saying,

1223.text: “This is great, what do we have in this in this agency?”

1226.text: We have 500 community enterprises, social enterprises throughout Africa.

1232.text: And tough places, Mali, Niger, Burkina Faso, Somalia, DRC,

1239.text: And we’re doing these grants and we are doing operational assistance,

1243.text: And I said, “Great, 500, sixty million invested in them, just great.

1248.text: Who are the ones that are really linking to follow-on funding, or linking to others?”

1253.text: You know, it was like this room, it was crickets.

1255.text: They were like, “Oh, they have to go somewhere?”

1258.text: I said,  “We have a tag line that says ‘Creating Pathways to Prosperity’,

1264.text: And we had to really get smarter around saying,

1267.text: you know, we’re in an educational institution, so let’s say it like this,

1271.text: we help them through high school and we even get them to college,

1274.text: but every college predicates its success, and where their graduates go,

1279.text: and how much money they make.

1281.text: So, where did our grantees, these early stage investees,

1286.text: these agricultural off-grid energy, youth enterprises,

1289.text: where did they go after we stopped?

1291.text: And we didn’t have answers for that.

1292.text: So we had to think about really adapting our model and saying,

1295.text: we probably need to find out what Cherie Blair Foundation,

1300.text: what Coca-Cola and others are looking for, so when we leave,

1304.text: when we stop our funding, and go and find and let another thousand flowers bloom,

1309.text: So, we had to create a new sort of level to really think about a real continuum,

1314.text: and it was sort of a eureka moment.

1316.text: Because it was like, you know, we’re making grants,

1318.text: we feel really good about ourselves,

1319.text: we can say in volume how many grants we’re making,

1322.text: and we even look at revenue generation,

1324.text: but we didn’t really think about these organizations that have a pathway,

1330.text: a continuum, to really keep increasing.

1332.text: And that was, again, it was a moment in time where we said,

1335.text: it’s about what we do, but it’s about what happens after we stop doing,

1340.text: and that’s really one way that we had to adapt.

1346.text: Shall we just go down the line?

1349.text: I’m very interested in what you said because  before I started the Foundation,

1354.text: for ten years in Downing Street, every week I did a charitable reception

1360.text: and saw loads of charities, both nationally and internationally,

1364.text: and it did strike me sometimes that there was a lot of duplication going on

1368.text: and sometimes just a lot of things continuing

1371.text: because that’s just what we’ve always done.

1373.text: And so when I set up the Foundation I was very clear that we needed to make sure

1377.text: that everything we did, there was a reason for it,

1379.text: and at the end that we always worked out, did it actually work?

1383.text: Because if it doesn’t work, you should stop doing it and try and do something else.

1388.text: And so with all our programs, we’ve just,

1392.text: last year we did an analysis of our mentoring program

1395.text: and we got an independent class of work associates

1398.text: to assess whether actually remote mentoring really works.

1402.text: Fortunately, they gave us the thumbs up, so that was good.

1407.text: With our mobile phone programs, we did this Business Woman’s App

1413.text: where we reached over 70,000 women in Nigeria and 100,000 women

1420.text: overall in Tanzania, Nigeria and Indonesia.

1423.text: You know, but again, does it make any difference sending a woman a text message,

1427.text: as we were doing, four text messages a week,

1493.text: So again, our ideas have developed because of this.

1499.text: Our Blended Learning Program that we’re doing at the moment,

1502.text: we’ve done thanks to Exxon Mobil in Nigeria,

1507.text: and another program that we’ve done in Malaysia, with the help of Qualcomm,

1511.text: where we gave small tablet computers to groups of women entrepreneurs there

1518.text: and free access to the internet and they came onto our mentoring program.

1521.text: We’ve had them independently assessed to see, well, does it work,

1527.text: But just  as a small example, in our Enterprise Development Program,

1534.text: we’ve developed this business skills training for women,

1537.text: which we did in Palestine and we were doing in parts of the Lebanon,

1542.text: then we moved up to the Bekaa Valley.

1558.text: when you’re talking about business training

1598.text: Another example, I said with our mobile phones,

1602.text: we did this whole work with mobile phone companies and banks.

1611.text: And what we were doing is we were giving business training to women

1614.text: and at the end they were given by the mobile phone company,

1622.text: I don’t need to explain to you, I hope, what happens with the mobile money.

1626.text: But to do that you have to first buy your block of mobile phone time,

1632.text: and so we’d entered into deals with local banks,

1636.text: to allow the women when they’d been trained, to go and get credit from the banks.
